Pemphigus vulgaris is a rare autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by blisters and erosions caused by detachment of adhesions between stratified squamous epithelial cells (acantholysis) on skin and mucous membranes. Oropharyngeal erosions are common and are frequently the presenting manifestation. Affected skin has flaccid blisters that generally develop on noninflamed skin; are readily broken; and progress to large, weeping, denuded areas. NSAIDs, rifampin, cephalosporins, captopril, and penicillamine have been associated with this condition.
